title: 105_s1395
content: The Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program is added as section 402I to the Higher Education Act of 1965, providing educational opportunities in the legal field. The Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program, added to the Higher Education Act of 1965, aims to assist low-income, minority, or disadvantaged college students in accessing and completing law school through information, preparation, and financial aid. Eligibility criteria include being from a low-income family, a minority, or from a disadvantaged background. The Secretary can contract with the Council on Legal Education Opportunity to identify eligible students for at least a 5-year period. The Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program aims to assist low-income, minority, or disadvantaged college students in accessing and completing law school through information, preparation, and financial aid. Services provided include preparing students for study at accredited law schools, assisting with law school selection and application, providing support services for first-year law students, and motivating students for law school studies and practice in low-income communities. Services are delivered through prelaw information resource centers, summer institutes, midyear seminars, and other educational activities. Services provided under the Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program include information and counseling on accredited law school programs, tutoring for bar examinations, prelaw mentoring programs, and assistance in identifying preparatory courses. The Thurgood Marshall Legal Educational Opportunity Program offers assistance in identifying preparatory courses and material for law school aptitude tests, summer institutes for Fellows emphasizing legal skills, and midyear seminars to reinforce study skills. Services can be provided before, during, and after law school. The Council on Legal Education Opportunity will subcontract and make subgrants to various institutions for providing services. The Secretary will set the maximum stipend for Thurgood Marshall Fellows participating in summer institutes and midyear seminars, based on academic progress. The Secretary will allocate up to $5,000,000 for services under this chapter, based on academic progress and qualifications for Doctor or Bachelor of Laws degree.
